DOC.HEAD: Dresser Industries Calls Off $620 Million Smith International Merger
DOC.TEXT: Dresser Industries Inc. has called off its $620 million offer for Smith International Inc., a Houston drill bit manufacturer, but the oil services company said it is pursuing an alternate transaction. In a one-paragraph news release on Thursday, Dallas-based Dresser said it was terminating the merger. No details were provided in the release about the alternative being considered and company officials declined to elaborate. When first announced in November, the companies said the deal was contingent upon approval by shareholders and federal antitrust regulators. Smith is the nation's second largest drill bit manufacturer and Dresser is No. 4. Some analysts speculated the Federal Trade Commission had expressed opposition to the transaction, which would have put 45 percent of the nation's drill bit industry in one company. Other analysts suggested Smith management may have decided to remain independent, or had found a better deal than the complicated Dresser cash, securities and debt-assumption offer. Yet others suggested Dresser had uncovered troubling information in its review of Smith's finances. Dresser had sought to buy Smith to broaden its base in the exploration and production side of the oil business, especially Smith's expertise in horizontal drilling, considered an important technique in the reviving industry.
